definitions.definition: (usually in phrases such as 'from the off', 'at the off', etc.) Beginning; starting point.
definitions.example: He has been very obviously an untrustworthy narrator right from the off.

definitions.definition: To kill.
definitions.example: He got in the way so I had him offed.

definitions.definition: To switch off.
definitions.example: Can you off the light?

definitions.definition: Inoperative, disabled.
definitions.example: All the lights are off.

definitions.definition: Cancelled; not happening.
definitions.example: The party's off because the hostess is sick.

definitions.definition: Not fitted; not being worn.
definitions.example: The drink spilled out of the bottle because the top was off.

definitions.definition: Rancid, rotten, gone bad.
definitions.example: This milk is off!

definitions.definition: Less than normal, in temperament or in result.
definitions.example: sales are off this quarter

definitions.definition: Inappropriate; untoward.
definitions.example: I felt that his comments were a bit off.

definitions.definition: (in phrases such as 'well off', 'better off', 'poorly off') Circumstanced.
Started on the way.
definitions.example: And they're off! Whatsmyname takes an early lead, with Remember The Mane behind by a nose.

definitions.definition: Far; off to the side.
definitions.example: He took me down the corridor and into an off room.

definitions.definition: Designating a time when one is not strictly attentive to business or affairs, or is absent from a post, and, hence, a time when affairs are not urgent.
definitions.example: He took an off day for fishing.  an off year in politics; the off season

definitions.definition: (in phrases such as 'off day') Designating a time when one is not performing to the best of one's abilities.
(of a dish on a menu) Presently unavailable.
definitions.example: — I'll have the chicken please.

definitions.definition: (in relation to a vehicle) On the side furthest from the kerb (the right-hand side if one drives on the left).
definitions.example: The off front wheel came loose.

definitions.definition: In, or towards the half of the field away from the batsman's legs; the right side for a right-handed batsman.
In a direction away from the speaker or object.
definitions.example: He drove off in a cloud of smoke.

definitions.definition: Into a state of non-operation or non-existence.
definitions.example: Please switch off the light when you leave.

definitions.definition: So as to remove or separate, or be removed or separated.
definitions.example: He bit off the end of the carrot.

definitions.definition: Used in various other ways specific to individual idiomatic phrases, e.g. bring off, show off, put off, tell off, etc. See the entry for the individual phrase.
Not positioned upon; away from a position upon.
definitions.example: He's off the roof now.

definitions.definition: Detached, separated, excluded or disconnected from; away from a position of attachment or connection to.
definitions.example: He was thrown off the team for cheating.

definitions.definition: Used to indicate the location or direction of one thing relative to another, implying adjacency or accessibility via.
definitions.example: His office is off this corridor on the right.

definitions.definition: Used to express location at sea relative to land or mainland.
definitions.example: The island is 23 miles off the cape.

definitions.definition: Removed or subtracted from.
definitions.example: There's 20% off the list price.

definitions.definition: No longer wanting or taking.
definitions.example: He's been off his feed since Tuesday.

definitions.definition: (more properly 'from') Out of the possession of.
definitions.example: He didn't buy it off him. He stole it off him.

definitions.definition: Placed after a number (of products or parts, as if a unit), in commerce or engineering.
definitions.example: I'd like to re-order those printer cartridges, let's say 5-off.
